facts.text: Appeal filed under Article 132 of the Constitution of India against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 361 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELATE JURISDICTION  Case No. 24 of 1050 . Appeal under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution of India, against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Criminal Miscellaneous Case No. 361 of 1050.

facts.text: High Court of Judicature at Calcutta rejected the habeas corpus petitions of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of Kania C.J., Fazl Ali, Mukherjea and Chandrasekhara Aiyar JJ., was delivered by Kania C.J. Patanjali Sastri and Das JJ. delivered separate judgments. KANIA C.J.--This is an appeal under article 132 of the Constitution of India from the judgment of the High Court at Calcutta, which rejected the habeas companypus petitions of the appellants.

facts.text: Detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, served on the appellants on 26th February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, in all cases were served on the appellants on the 26th February, 1950, and the grounds for the detention were served on the 14th March, 1950.

facts.text: Grounds for detention served on the appellants on 14th March 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The detention orders under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, in all cases were served on the appellants on the 26th February, 1950, and the grounds for the detention were served on the 14th March, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants assisted operations of the Communist Party of India, declared unlawful under section 16 of the Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act 1908.

anchor.surface_text: By way of specimen we quote one of them You are beings detained in pursuance of a detention order made under sub-clause  ii  of clause  a  of subsection  1 of section a of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950,  Act IV of 1950 , on the following grounds- That you have been assisting the operations of the Communist Party of India, which along with its volunteer organisations has been declared unlawful by Government under section 16 of the Indian Criminal Law Amendment Act  Act XIV of 1908 ,

facts.text: Appellant was a member of the C.P.I. on its Kishan front and fomented trouble amongst peasants of Howrah District, inciting lawlessness and violence.

anchor.surface_text: That as a member of the C.P.I. on its Kishan front, you have fomented trouble amongst the peasants of Howrah District and incited them to acts of lawlessness and vio- lence and have thereby acted in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

facts.text: Appellant as a worker of the C.P.I. tried to foment trouble amongst tramways men and other workers at Calcutta and incited violence in speeches at University Hall.

anchor.surface_text: That as a worker of the C.P.I. you have tried to foment trouble amongst the tramways men and other workers at Cal- cutta and in speeches which you delivered at the University Hall and other places you actually incited them to resort to acts of violence and lawlessness

facts.text: Government of West Bengal served supplementary grounds for detention on appellants on 16th July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th of July, 1950, the Government of West Bengal served on the appellants in companytinuation of the grounds already furnished on the 14th of March, 1950, supplementary grounds for their detention

facts.text: Appellant as Secretary of Bengal Chatkar Mazdoor Union led procession at Howrah on 29th July 1948 preaching discontent against Government.

anchor.surface_text: You as the Secretary of the Bengal Chatkar Mazdoor Union, as a member of the Executive Committee of the Federa- tion of Mercantile Employees Union, as the honorary report- er of the Khabar newspaper  C. P.I. organ  carried on the disruptive programme of the C.P.I. On the 29th July, 1948, you along with others led a procession at Howrah

facts.text: Appellants applied for Rule of habeas corpus separately under section 491 of CrPC; High Court issued Rule on 21st July 1950 to Chief Secretary, Government of West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applied for a Rule of habeas companypus separate- ly under section 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code and on the 21st July, 1950, the High Court issued a Rule in each case on the Chief Secretary to the Government of West Ben- gal.

facts.text: Second set of grounds communicated to appellants on 22nd or 23rd July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: A second set of grounds were companymunicated to the appellants on the 22nd or 23rd of July, 1950.

facts.text: In meeting on 19th March 1947 under Calcutta Tramway Workers Union, appellant threatened disaster if tram cars taken out on 20th March 1947 and said would remove tram lines.

anchor.surface_text: That in a meeting held at the University Institute on the 19th March, 1947, under the auspices of the Calcutta Tramway Workers Union, you held out the threat that any attempt to take out tram cars on the 20th March, 1947, would be inviting disaster and you further said that if the au- thorities tried to resume the tram service you and your friends would number hesitate to remove the tram lines and cut the wires.

facts.text: On 13th June 1948, appellant presided over meeting under Students Federation (CPI controlled) advocating withdrawal of ban on CPI and Swadhinta.

anchor.surface_text: That on the 13th June, 1948, you presided over a meeting under the auspices of the Students Federation P.I. companytrolled  and delivered speech advocating withdrawal of ban on the Communist Party of India and its organ Swadhinta.

facts.text: Under Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act 1930, a very large number of persons were detained.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Bengal Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1930, a very large number of persons were detained. The validity of that Act was being challenged in the High Court

facts.text: Preventive Detention Act 1950 passed by Parliament in the last week of February 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Preventive Detention Act, 1950, was passed by the Parliament of India in the last week of February, 1950, and these orders on all those detenus were served on the 26th of February, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants contended that grounds of 14th March 1950 not communicated as soon as may be per Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, it was first companytended on behalf of the appellants that the companymunication of the grounds dated the 14th March was number a companypliance with article 22  5 of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were number companymu- nicated as soon as may be.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that grounds of 14th March 1950 complied with Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this companytention. Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnish- ing the grounds dated the 14th of March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22  5  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 are not new grounds but details of earlier grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the companytents of the later companymunication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds

facts.text: High Court considered grounds not vague and procedural requirements complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has companysidered the case of each appellant in respect of the companymunication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are number vague.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Large number of fresh detention orders made overnight under new Act after local Acts validity in doubt.

anchor.surface_text: One additional point raised in this appeal was that the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities

facts.text: Authorities had already applied minds to each detenu under local Acts before making fresh orders.

anchor.surface_text: The authorities had already applied their minds to the suspected activities of each of the detenus and were satisfied that with a view to prevent them from doing some prejudicial act of a particular kind it was necessary to make an order of detention against them under the local Acts.

arguments.claim: The communication of the grounds dated the 14th March was not a compliance with article 22(5) of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were not communicated as soon as may be.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, it was first contended on behalf of the appellants that the communication of the grounds dated the 14th March was not a compliance with article 22 (5) of the Constitution of India, as those grounds were not communicated as soon as may be.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ibed it as in companytinuation of the grounds already furnished and as the supplementary grounds for your detention. Relying on the wording

arguments.court_reasoning: Agree with High Court; circumstances of sudden large number of cases after local Act challenge justify delay.

arguments.claim: There has been non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22(5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds resulting in not providing the earliest opportunity to make a representation.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was next urged that there has been non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22 (5) of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants resulting in not providing to the appellants the earliest opportunity to make a representation,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ended that the fact of this companymunication showed that the authorities were number satisfied on the origi- nal grounds and had therefore put forth

arguments.court_reasoning: Apply principles from Case No. 22 of 1950; no infringement found.

arguments.claim: The supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 are additional or new grounds which were not communicated as soon as may be under article 22(5); obligation is absolute; shows authorities not satisfied on original grounds, afterthought.

anchor.surface_text: When the authorities sent their second communication dated 16th July, 1950, to the appellants they described it as in continuation of the grounds already furnished and as the supplementary grounds for your detention. Relying on the wording of this communication it was argued that these were additional grounds which were furnished to the detenu and therefore the procedure prescribed under article 22 (5) had not been followed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: March, they cannot support the detention on additional grounds which were number before them on that day and which they set out in the second company

arguments.court_reasoning: Not new grounds but details of earlier heads; contents matter not description; not necessarily afterthought; principles from Case No. 22 and 92.

arguments.claim: The grounds being vague, they could not be considered as grounds at all and therefore they could not be sufficient to satisfy the authorities under section 3.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued that the grounds being vague, they could not be considered as grounds at all and therefore they could not be sufficient to satisfy the authorities.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ral law and we see numberreason to companye to a different companyclusion. It was next argued that the grounds being vague, they companyld number be c

arguments.court_reasoning: Vague grounds not same as irrelevant; two distinct objects - govt satisfaction not reviewable, only sufficiency for representation; per Case No. 22.

arguments.claim: Vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds; court can examine sufficiency of grounds for authority's subjective satisfaction under section 3.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention that vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds. An irrelevant ground has no connection at all with the satisfaction of the Provincial Government which makes the order of detention.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ral law and we see numberreason to companye to a different companyclusion. It was next argued that the grounds being vague, they companyld number be c

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguish irrelevant (vitiates) from vague; separate tests for satisfaction (non-justiciable) and representation (justiciable sufficiency).

arguments.claim: The fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities as they could not have applied their minds to each individual case.

anchor.surface_text: One additional point raised in this appeal was that the fact that a large number of fresh orders of detention were made overnight indicates bad faith on the part of the authorities, for the authorities could not have applied their minds to each individual case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: r have applied their minds to each individual case. I am unable to accept this companytention as companyrect. The authorities had already applied thei

arguments.court_reasoning: Authorities already applied minds under local Acts; no need for elaborate fresh consideration given prior satisfaction and new Act passage.

arguments.claim: Having regard to the sudden large number of cases, the grounds of 14th March were communicated as soon as may be, complying with Art 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this contention. Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th of March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22 (5) of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Supplementary grounds of 16th July are not new but furnish details of earlier grounds of 14th March.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the contents of the later communication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds

arguments.claim: Grounds are not vague; procedural requirements complied with, enabling representation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: two objects. The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satis- faction of the Provincia

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court sees no reason to differ.

arguments.claim: Sufficiency of grounds for authority's satisfaction under S.3 is not examinable by court; only sufficiency for detenu's representation under Art 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. The sufficiency of the grounds to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation can be examined by the court, but only from that point of view.

holdings.text: The furnishing of grounds dated 14th March 1950 complied with Article 22(5) of the Constitution as they were communicated as soon as may be under the circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this contention. Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th of March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22  5  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sudden large number of detentions after local Act challenge and passage of new central Act justified 17-day delay; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: No non-compliance with Article 22(5) and section 7 of Preventive Detention Act in supplying grounds; earliest opportunity to make representation provided.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was next urged that there has been non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22  s of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants resulting in not providing to the appellants the earliest opportunity to make a representation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles discussed in Case No. 22 of 1950 regarding two rights under Art 22(5); no infringement found.

holdings.text: Supplementary grounds of 16th July 1950 are not new or additional grounds but details elaborating earlier grounds of 14th March 1950, complying with Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: Examining the contents of the later communication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contents matter over description; elaborative details not new; applies principles from Case Nos. 22 and 92 of 1950; not afterthought.

holdings.text: Vague grounds do not stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds; irrelevant grounds vitiate detention but vague ones do not necessarily.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention that vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds. An irrelevant ground has no connection at all with the satisfaction of the Provincial Government which makes the order of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes concepts; irrelevant lacks connection to satisfaction, vague may still enable representation; per Case No. 22.

holdings.text: Court cannot examine sufficiency of grounds for detaining authority's subjective satisfaction under section 3; can only examine for detenu's opportunity to make representation under Article 22(5).

anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. The sufficiency of the grounds to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation can be examined by the court, but only from that point of view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two distinct objects/tests; satisfaction non-justiciable, representation justiciable for procedural compliance; mixes up rejected.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention dated 14th March 1950 not vague; procedural requirements under Article 22(5) complied with, enabling representation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation has not been infringed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with High Court's individual assessment; no reason to differ; not seriously pressed.

holdings.text: No bad faith in making large number of fresh detention orders overnight under new Act; prior application of mind under local Acts suffices.

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to accept this contention as correct. The authorities had already applied their minds to the suspected activities of each of the detenus and were satisfied that with a view to prevent them from doing some prejudicial act of a particular kind it was necessary to make an order of detention against them under the local Acts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Minds already applied under prior local Acts whose validity doubted; new Act passage required fresh orders, no elaborate re-application needed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected this contention. Under the circumstances of the case, we agree with the High Court and are unable to hold that in furnishing the grounds dated the 14th of March, 1950, the authorities had failed to act in accordance with the procedure laid down in article 22  5  of the Constitution.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants it was next urged that there has been non-compliance with the procedure laid down in article 22  s of the Constitution and section 7 of the Preventive Detention Act in the manner of supplying grounds to the appellants resulting in not providing to the appellants the earliest opportunity to make a representation,
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

Examining the contents of the later communication in that way we find that they only furnish details of the second heads of the grounds furnished to the appropriate appellant on 14th March, 1950, in respect of his activities. We are unable to treat them as new grounds
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention that vague grounds stand on the same footing as irrelevant grounds. An irrelevant ground has no connection at all with the satisfaction of the Provincial Government which makes the order of detention.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The sufficiency of the grounds, which gives rise to the satisfaction of the Provincial Government, is not a matter for examination by the court. anchor.surface_text: The High Court has considered the case of each appellant in respect of the communication dated the 14th of March, 1950, sent to him. In their opinion those grounds are not vague. They have held that the procedural requirement to give the detained person the earliest opportunity to make a representation has not been infringed
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: I am unable to accept this contention as correct. The authorities had already applied their minds to the suspected activities of each of the detenus and were satisfied that with a view to prevent them from doing some prejudicial act of a particular kind it was necessary to make an order of detention against them under the local Acts.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.
